figure_1.title: Figure 1. Barriers to availability of blood transfusions for blood cancer patients in hospice.
figure_1.caption:
“To what extent do the following factors contribute to lack of availability of blood transfusions for blood cancer patients enrolled in your hospice?”
Assessed among 106 participants who noted that transfusions were never or only sometimes offered to patients with blood cancers enrolled in their hospice and answered all 3 questions about barriers to transfusions

figure_2.title: Figure 2. Barriers to Hospice Care for Patients with Blood Cancers.
figure_2.caption:
“To what extent do you think each of the following is a barrier to hospice care for patients with blood cancers?”
Assessed among 111 participants who answered all questions regarding barriers to hospice care

figure_3.title: Figure 3. Interventions to Increase Rates of Hospice Enrollment for Patients with Blood Cancers.
figure_3.caption:
“How helpful do you think the following changes would be at increasing rates of hospice enrollment for patients with hematologic malignancies?”
Assessed among 111 participants who answered all questions regarding barriers to hospice care

claims.sentence: Figure 1 depicts perspectives regarding barriers to transfusion availability in hospice among agencies that never or only sometimes offered transfusions.
The extent to which other factors were considered barriers are depicted in Figure 2.

Other interventions reported to be very helpful include increased collaboration between hematologic oncologists and hospice providers (67.6%) and policies allowing concurrent cancer-directed care and hospice care (65.8%; Figure 3).
